instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage not turning on
threads.message:
Hi Guys,

I have an 820-000145 2015 Macbook 12 inch thats liquid damaged. The charge port cable had a corroded pin, swapped that out. The Mac does not start. I know I need 20V on F4700 pin 1. What I get there is a voltage between 0-5v thats seems to turn on and off rapidly, unlike in the video from Louis where it showed a stable 5V. What could be the issue? It looks like no liquid has reached the logicboard, checked carefully with a microscope. The OAN line is also pulsing, between 0-2.9v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage not turning on
threads.message: Using the correct DCIN cable, there are a few different ones. Checked rails for shorts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage not turning on
threads.message: Yes im using the correct one. No short on F4700 and diode measurement gives me 0.546v on pin 1. Will got through all rails now to check for a short and report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage not turning on
threads.message:
Short on CPU? I believe all shorted lines lead to the CPU :(?

PPBUS =  0.470
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.535
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> = 0.469
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_E85</SIGNAL> = 0.547
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.567
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.407
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> = 0.338
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.267
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0.425
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.380
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage not turning on
threads.message: Uhh if that many rails are shorted then yes this is RIP. Do check on Ohm setting if they are really shorted though.
